repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: I wonder if it's even correct that we create two separate module scopes. And a good thing. It seems to me that the answer might be no.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1351,6 +1352,17 @@ def declare_builtin(self, name, pos):
         entry.qualified_name = self.builtin_scope().qualify_name(name)
         return entry
 
+    def _is_package_scope_or_module(self):
+        # Returns True for all ModuleScopes representing package or scopes representing
+        # modules. Otherwise returns False.
+        # Note: For package pkg_a Cython creates two modules scopes: pkg_a and pkg_a.__init__.

comment_data.body: This will probably be reworked, but it seems wasteful to do something as expensive as this as part of a loop, even though it's obvious that the result will never change. Which, BTW, seems problematic. My guess is that you'd want to check parent packages as well, not just the package directory itself.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1362,7 +1374,7 @@ def find_module(self, module_name, pos, relative_level=-1):
             # explicit relative cimport
             # error of going beyond top-level is handled in cimport node
             relative_to = self
-            while relative_level > 0 and relative_to:
+            while relative_level > 0 and relative_to and self._is_package_scope_or_module():

comment_data.body: This part was removed, in order to fix failing TC introduced in: https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4552/commits/bd361e215277f81d1ac358269adf34879007e804
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8569,9 +8569,6 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if not env.is_module_scope:
             error(self.pos, "cimport only allowed at module level")
             return
-        if self.relative_level and self.relative_level > env.qualified_name.count('.'):
-            error(self.pos, "relative cimport beyond main package is not allowed")
-            return

+            while relative_level > 0 and relative_to and self._is_package_scope_or_module():

comment_data.body: You already have a better implementation in `_split_qualified_name()`. You could turn that into a helper function (and add `__init__.pxd`).
It's supposed to reject cimports like `from ........ cimport x` that go beyond the main package level (as the error message suggests). It seems that we would still want that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8569,9 +8569,6 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if not env.is_module_scope:
             error(self.pos, "cimport only allowed at module level")
             return
-        if self.relative_level and self.relative_level > env.qualified_name.count('.'):
-            error(self.pos, "relative cimport beyond main package is not allowed")
-            return

comment_data.body: Maybe call this argument `as_package`, to make it clearer that it refers to the module that is being looked for and for which a module scope should be created.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1386,7 +1368,7 @@ def find_module(self, module_name, pos, relative_level=-1):
         return module_scope.context.find_module(
             module_name, relative_to=relative_to, pos=pos, absolute_fallback=absolute_fallback)
 
-    def find_submodule(self, name):
+    def find_submodule(self, name, is_package=False):

comment_data.body: You may want to use `list.pop()` here to avoid the slicing below.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,6 +143,21 @@ def process_pxd(self, source_desc, scope, module_name):
     def nonfatal_error(self, exc):
         return Errors.report_error(exc)
 
+    def _split_qualified_name(self, qualified_name):
+        # Splits qualified_name into parts in form of 2-tuples: (PART_NAME, IS_PACKAGE).
+        qualified_name_parts = qualified_name.split('.')
+        last_part = qualified_name_parts[-1]

comment_data.body: This duplication seems wasteful. And it's also not what (I think) we do normally. I think we rather prefer the first that we find, regardless of the type. There probably code for that already.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,6 +143,21 @@ def process_pxd(self, source_desc, scope, module_name):
     def nonfatal_error(self, exc):
         return Errors.report_error(exc)
 
+    def _split_qualified_name(self, qualified_name):
+        # Splits qualified_name into parts in form of 2-tuples: (PART_NAME, IS_PACKAGE).
+        qualified_name_parts = qualified_name.split('.')
+        last_part = qualified_name_parts[-1]
+        qualified_name_parts = [(p, True) for p in qualified_name_parts[:-1]]
+        if last_part != '__init__':
+            # If Last part is __init__, then it is omitted. Otherwise, we need to check whether we can find
+            # __init__.pyx/__init__.py file to determine if last part is package or not.
+            path = self.search_include_directories(qualified_name, suffix='.pyx')
+            if not path:
+                path = self.search_include_directories(qualified_name, suffix='.py')

@@ -143,6 +143,23 @@ def process_pxd(self, source_desc, scope, module_name):
     def nonfatal_error(self, exc):
         return Errors.report_error(exc)
 
+    def _split_qualified_name(self, qualified_name):
+        # Splits qualified_name into parts in form of 2-tuples: (PART_NAME, IS_PACKAGE).
+        qualified_name_parts = qualified_name.split('.')
+        last_part = qualified_name_parts.pop()
+        qualified_name_parts = [(p, True) for p in qualified_name_parts]
+        if last_part != '__init__':
+            # If Last part is __init__, then it is omitted. Otherwise, we need to check whether we can find
+            # __init__.pyx/__init__.py file to determine if last part is package or not.
+            paths = self.find_file_with_suffix(qualified_name, suffix=('.pyx', '.py'))
+            is_package = self._is_init_file(paths[0]) if len(paths) > 0 else False

comment_data.body:
When this change is not present following case is failing:

Suppose we have following package:
```
pkg/
  + __init__.pyx
  + __init__pxd
  + sub/
     + __init__.pyx
     + __init__.pxd
```
And `pkg/__init__.pyx` contains following line:

```cython
from . cimport sub
```

Command `cythonize -3ib __init__.pyx` fails with following:
```
Compiling /Users/matus/dev/cython/test/pkg/__init__.pyx because it changed.
[1/1] Cythonizing /Users/matus/dev/cython/test/pkg/__init__.pyx
> /Users/matus/dev/cython/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py(8576)analyse_declarations()
-> error(self.pos, "relative cimport beyond main package is not allowed")
(Pdb) c

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
from . cimport sub
^
------------------------------------------------------------

__init__.pyx:1:0: relative cimport beyond main package is not allowed
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/matus/dev/cython39/bin/cythonize", line 33, in <module>
    sys.exit(load_entry_point('Cython', 'console_scripts', 'cythonize')())
  File "/Users/matus/dev/cython/Cython/Build/Cythonize.py", line 224, in main
    cython_compile(path, options)
  File "/Users/matus/dev/cython/Cython/Build/Cythonize.py", line 68, in cython_compile
    ext_modules = cythonize(
  File "/Users/matus/dev/cython/Cython/Build/Dependencies.py", line 1117, in cythonize
    cythonize_one(*args)
  File "/Users/matus/dev/cython/Cython/Build/Dependencies.py", line 1284, in cythonize_one
    raise CompileError(None, pyx_file)
Cython.Compiler.Errors.CompileError: /Users/matus/dev/cython/test/pkg/__init__.pyx
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         if not env.is_module_scope:

             return
-        if self.relative_level and self.relative_level > env.qualified_name.count('.'):
+        if self.relative_level and self.relative_level > len(env.qualified_name.split('.')):

comment_data.body: This looks like a simple variable `top_level` (0/1) could avoid the code duplication. The comments are helpful, though.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1421,9 +1415,18 @@ def find_module(self, module_name, pos, relative_level=-1):
             # explicit relative cimport
             # error of going beyond top-level is handled in cimport node
             relative_to = self
-            while relative_level > 0 and relative_to:
-                relative_to = relative_to.parent_module
-                relative_level -= 1
+            if self.is_package:
+                # When file is __init__.pyx, current package is current module
+                # i.e. dot in `from . import ...` points to current package
+                while relative_level > 1 and relative_to:
+                    relative_to = relative_to.parent_module
+                    relative_level -= 1
+            else:
+                # When file is regular module, current package is parent module
+                # i.e. dot in `from . import ...` points to package where module is placed
+                while relative_level > 0 and relative_to:
+                    relative_to = relative_to.parent_module
+                    relative_level -= 1

comment_data.body: Can we somehow use code generation for the package directory structure and test files? They look generated, and if we ever want to add something to this test, I'm sure we'd forget to add some (c)import in one or two of them.

comment_data.body: It might be clearer (for user and implementation) to have different error messages for the two cases.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8728,9 +8728,14 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if not env.is_module_scope:
             error(self.pos, "cimport only allowed at module level")
             return
-        if self.relative_level and self.relative_level > env.qualified_name.count('.'):
-            error(self.pos, "relative cimport beyond main package is not allowed")
-            return
+        qualified_name_components = env.qualified_name.count('.') + 1
+        if self.relative_level:
+            if self.relative_level > qualified_name_components or (
+                    self.relative_level == qualified_name_components and not env.is_package):
+                # 1. case: importing beyond package: from .. import pkg
+                # 2. case: importing from same level but current dir is not package: from . import module
+                error(self.pos, "relative cimport beyond main package is not allowed")

comment_data.body:
Isn't it enough to find one here and break? We do this for every module that we look up. That's expensive.

Also, I think I'd prefer a name like `find_module_file`. And since we don't use the `.pxd` suffix, just remove it.

And, finally, I'm not sure that we should split the search by extension here and not by include directory (i.e. search each directory for all extensions and then go to the next directory). The latter seems more reasonable to me since users can influence the order of include directories but not the order of the extensions.

Hmm. I think it would be best to inline this function into `_split_qualified_name`. It's not as generic as it may seem, it's actually very specific to that method. And actually making it a specific part of that method would allow simplifying and optimising the algorithm.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -254,6 +271,15 @@ def find_pyx_file(self, qualified_name, pos=None, source_file_path=None):
         return self.search_include_directories(
             qualified_name, suffix=".pyx", source_pos=pos, source_file_path=source_file_path)
 
+    def find_file_with_suffix(self, qualified_name, pos=None, source_file_path=None, suffix=('.py', '.pyx', '.pxd')):
+        found = []
+        for s in suffix:
+            path = self.search_include_directories(
+                qualified_name, suffix=s, source_pos=pos, source_file_path=source_file_path)
+            if path:
+                found.append(path)
+        return found

comment_data.body:
> Is there anywhere a way how to do it or I need to do it from scratch?

We don't have a specific framework to do this kind of thing

If it was generated then I'd probably suggest either:
* including the generation script in the commit (maybe Tools/), or
* putting the script as part of a srctree file and run it as step 1 (instead of including the output in the srctree file)

Given they aren't generated I don't think this requires a change. It would just have been a shame not to have the script if it already existed.

comment_data.body: No unfortunatelly I don't have such tool... So I am resolving the conversion. Please let me know if there is anything blocking this PR being accepted.

+PYTHON -c "import test_cimport"

commit.message: Fix relative imports in __init__ files by searching __init__ file of ModuleScope
Added additional TC or relative import in __init__.py
Pass package information about ModuleScope as __init__ parameter.
Move splitting qualified name logic to separate method
Use pop() instead of index access using []
Rename parameter of find_submodule from is_package to as_package

Revert "Remove error causing failing tests"

This reverts commit b2e326f280524de7f57046d4059aa46516375ead.
Introduce back relative cimport beyond main package is not allowed error

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Fix failing relative imports in __init__ files.
